summary: This is a discovery letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to defense counsel in the case 'United States v. Robert Adams', providing additional materials and summarizing witness interviews related to an investigation into contraband smuggling at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in connection with the Jeffrey Epstein death investigation. The document details statements from multiple witnesses, including a visitor (Visitor-1), inmates, and correctional staff, regarding the defendant's alleged conduct.

persons.name: Robert Adams
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, a correctional officer at the MCC accused of involvement with contraband smuggling and improper conduct with a visitor.

persons.name: Samuel Gregory
persons.context: Attorney for the defendant Robert Adams, recipient of this discovery letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the deceased inmate whose death at the MCC prompted the broader investigation into circumstances at the facility.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who signed this discovery letter.

connections.description: Visitor-1 alleges Robert Adams was romantically interested in her, gave her his phone number, and she planned to obtain money from him. Adams allegedly told her not to bring drugs to the MCC anymore.
Inmate-2 stated that Adams intercepted contraband from an inmate named 'Lucky' and said he would flush it.
CO-1, a fellow correctional officer, provided a positive character assessment of Adams, stating he did not believe Adams would do favors for inmates or visitors.
Supervisor-1 reported that Adams confided about personal issues (heart problem, marital trouble, excessive drinking) and denied allegations from Visitor-1.

events.title: Contraband Incident at MCC
events.description: Visitor-1 allegedly brought contraband to the MCC. Robert Adams later told Visitor-1 he threw it away. This date is also referenced for MCC surveillance footage.

events.title: Interview of Robert Adams
events.description: A paralegal at the U.S. Attorney's Office spoke to Robert Adams by telephone regarding his work schedule as part of the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: Post-Arrest Conversation with FBI
events.description: After his arrest and release, Robert Adams was walked out of the courthouse by FBI agents and discussed food options, recommending Luna Pizzeria near the MCC.

events.title: Text Messages from Visitor-1
events.description: Visitor-1 sent text messages stating 'the fed was there he blowing mines' (frustration at being prevented from visiting) and that she 'bagged one of the feds' (got his phone number) and might get money from him.

keyFacts: The document is part of the discovery in 'United States v. Robert Adams', a case stemming from an investigation into contraband smuggling and circumstances surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death at the MCC.

Visitor-1 made multiple allegations against Robert Adams, including that he took her phone number, was romantically interested in her, prevented her from visiting an inmate, and discussed her 'dry month' (not making money from smuggling).

Multiple other witnesses (inmates, correctional officers, a supervisor) were interviewed, providing mixed accountsâ€”some supporting Adams's professionalism, others implicating him in contraband interception.

The investigation involved extensive records collection: MCC visitor logs, surveillance footage, phone records (Sprint, Verizon, Nile), financial records, and materials from Adams's cellphone and Visitor-1's phone.
Robert Adams reportedly told his supervisor he had personal issues including a heart problem, marital troubles, and excessive drinking, while denying the allegations against him.
